repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Agricultural Support Services,
            and Agricultural Research Management Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
This audit downgrades the Implementation
            Completion Report's (ICR) assessment of the
            Agricultural Research Management Project (ARMP) to
            moderately unsatisfactory project outcomes, to an unlikely
            sustainability, and with an unsatisfactory Bank performance,
            though concurs with the ICR on modest institutional
            development impacts, and satisfactory Borrower performance
            ratings. Similarly, the audit downgrades the Agricultural
            Support Services Project (ASSP) ICR's ratings, to
            moderately satisfactory project outcomes, and considers
            sustainability as non-evaluable, while concurs with a modest
            institutional development impact, and satisfactory
            performances by the Bank, and Borrower. The lessons, largely
            consistent with findings on research, and extension in other
            countries, suggest the diagnosis of constraints emerging
            during project preparation, should lead to a set of reforms
            identifying the minimum for an effective project, clearly
            articulated, within the evolving Bank management
            documentation. In addition, the adoption of new unified
            national extension approaches, should be based on evaluated
            cost-effectiveness data, though it is important to maintain
            experimentation with alternative approaches to further
            pursue cost-effectiveness. While cutting research costs by
            institutional rationalization (i.e., closing of stations) is
            politically difficult, it is seldom addressed by neither the
            Bank, nor the Borrower, yet should be pursued. Therefore, a
            thorough analysis of project financial sustainability should
            be considered at appraisal time, rather than focusing mainly
            on funding during implementation. Other lessons address the
            need to focus on procurement issues based on intensive early
            supervision, and, introduction of computerized management
            systems, should be matched to the level of computer skills,
            and technical support capacity.

abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated as
            satisfactory, and sustainability is rated as likely. Overall
            performances of both the World Bank and the Borrower is
            evaluated as satisfactory. Lessons learned are the
            following: 1) Sustainability of research projects with a
            heavy emphasis on institutional development will not come
            about simply by securing continuous donor funding.
            Sustainability can only be achieved by research
            organizations developing management skills and processes to
            allow work on priority research to continue even in the face
            of reduced budgets envelopes, through strict financial
            management and by ensuring appropriate staffing levels are
            maintained. 2) The effectiveness of technical assistance and
            training would be increased if programs are well coordinated
            and linked technically to ensure they complement each other,
            and implemented early in the project to allow benefits
            coming from these activities to be felt during
            implementation and to allow new processes to be
            institutionalized before the project ends. In some cases,
            this might mean outsourcing management of these programs. 3)
            Procurement management capacity must be assessed
            realistically at appraisal. 4) Project implementation units
            are neither necessary or desirable, as they tend to isolate
            project activities from the mainstream operations of
            implementing agencies, possibly depriving it of high-level
            support needed for effective implementation and longer term sustainability.

docna.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Agricultural Research
            Management Project : Credit 2815 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Bangladesh - Agricultural
            Research Management Project : Credit 2815 - Credit Agreement
            - Conformed

18155780.theme: Other rural development,Rural services and infrastructure

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Agricultural
            Research Management Project is to increase the efficiency of
            the national agricultural research system and thereby to
            generate profitable, relevant, and sustainable agricultural
            technologies for Bangladeshi agricultural producers. The
            components of the project are as follows: 1) research
            management and organization, which will strengthen
            managerial capabilities of Bangladesh Agricultural Research
            Council (BARC) through carrying out of institutional
            reforms, improved economic analysis of research programs,
            technical assistance, construction and rehabilitation of
            civil works, training, contract research, and supervision of
            new master plans for participating Agricultural Research
            Institutes (ARIs); 2) priority research, which will be
            carried out in the ARIs on crops, fisheries, livestock and
            forestry; and 3) participating farming systems research,
            which will strengthen farming systems research programs
            through support to research-extension linkages and testing
            and dissemination of appropriate technology.
